div.head: To the Reuerend Father in GOD, Thomas Morton Doctor in Diuinitie, and Lord Bishop of Couentrie and Lietchfield, I. F. wisheth grace in this life, and glorie in the world to come.
div.p:
WHEREAS the holy Ghost hath both recorded in the sixt Chapter of the Epistle to the Hebrewes, that short Catechisme, which the Apostles in their dayes taught those whom they conuerted to the faith of Christ, & also left the same to the Churches for all future times: I not doubting but that the euidence of the text, Heb. 5.12. and 6.1. Will iustifie this to bee the Apostles Catechisme, haue presumed to propound and expound
the same as the Lord hath inabled mee, hoping thereby to whet vp their gifts, which are better able to adorne and enlarge it; to iustifie other Catechismes, which differing from this in words, agree with it in substance; and to propound it as a paterne or an example for imitation, that they which of themselues are alreadie forward, may be incouraged to proceede, and those which are somewhat slacke, may bee prouoked diligently to plant the first principles in the hearts of those that are vnder their charge, and so yong plants may grow vp in their youth, and become worthie instruments in Church or Common-wealth, as God shall appoint. This small Treatise I haue presumed to dedicate to your Lordships for these reasons. First, because you are able to discerne of the matter handled herein. Secondly, because it hath beene
publikely taught to youth in your Lordships Dioces. Thirdly, because I haue great cause to giue some testimonie of heartie thankfulnesse to your Lordships great fauour, which I haue lately found at your hands. And desiring the small testimonie may bee accepted in good part, I cease at this present. Iune 5. 1623.
